LanguageData.ZP_RawWater.label: Natural Water
LanguageData.ZP_RawWater.description: Namamizu means "raw water," and raw is exactly how a colonist will feel if they drink this water. Puking one's guts out after drinking parasite filled water is a lesson that most try to avoid.
LanguageData.ZP_Water.label: Boiled Water
LanguageData.ZP_Water.description: From the Kanji "水," which can read as "Sui" or "Mizu:" though both mean "water." This water still bears some impurities, making it unfit for consumption; however, as most recipes call for boiling, it should be fine to cook with.
LanguageData.ZP_DrinkingWater.label: Mineral Water
LanguageData.ZP_DrinkingWater.description: Nomimizu, or "drinking water," can be used as a simple measure against heat stroke.\n\nBoth Inryōsui and Nomimizu mean "drinking water," which parrots the Mizu/Sui situation for "water;" however, in this case we can also observe that Nomi means "drinking," while Inryō means "beverage."
